section.title: Starting Cactus tests
section.p: The Cactus tests are started using a JUnit Test Runner. There are several configurations for executing these test runners:

ul.li: From Ant, by using the <junit> task
From the java command line, calling the main() method of a Test Runner.
From an IDE or any tool providing a JUnit integration plugin.
From a browser, by using the Cactus Servlet Test Runner, which is a special JUnit Test Runner.

Running Cactus tests from a browser
section.note: This section only applies for Cactus 1.4 and greater.

section.title: Step 1: Setting up the classpath
section.p: In order to run Cactus tests from a browser you need to have a webapp containing your classes to test and your test classes. In addition, both Cactus client side and server side jar classes must be able to be loaded from your webapp (i.e located in your WEB-INF/lib directory or in a location available through your container Context class loader (refer to your container documentation).
section.note: Refer to the Classpath Howto guide for the exact list of jars.

section.title: Step 2: Mapping the Cactus Servlet Test Runner
section.p: Then, in addition to the Cactus redirectors that you have mapped in your web.xml (see the Configuration howto), you also need to map the Cactus Servlet Test Runner, as follows:

section.title: Step 3: Executing the tests
section.p: Open a browser and type http://server:port/mywebapp/ServletTestRunner?suite=mytestcase where:

ul.li: server:port is the name of your server machine and port on which your container is running
mywebapp is the name of your webapp (usually the name of your war file)
mytestcase is the fully qualified name (i.e. with packages) of your TestCase class containing a suite() method listing all the tests, in standard JUnit fashion.

section.p: Ok, that's nice ... But what if I want HTML instead of XML? Don't worry there is a solution. Grab the following XSLT stylesheet (based on the stylesheet used by the <junitreport> Ant task), drop it in your webapp and name it cactus-report.xsl (in the root directory for example). Then, open a browser and type http://server:port/mywebapp/ServletTestRunner?suite=mytestcase&xsl=cactus-report.xsl. You should see the following:
section.note: This will work with Internet Explorer as the XSL transformation is performed on the client side (i.e by the browser). I'm not sure about other browsers.

section.title: Enabling Server-Side XSLT Transformations
section.p: In the previous section, the XSLT transformation was performed on the client. This requires a browser capable of doing XSLT transformations in a standards-compliant manner, and requires adding the location of the stylesheet as a request parameter.

Since Cactus 1.5, the ServletTestRunner can also perform the transformation on the server-side. To enable that feature, make sure that a JAXP compliant XSLT processor (such as Xalan) is available to the web-application.
In addition, the location of the XSLT stylesheet needs to specified as initialization parameter of the ServletTestRunner. For example:

The specified path is relative to the root of the web-application. Of course, the stylesheet needs to exist at that location. In contrast to client-side transformations, the stylesheet may be placed somewhere inside the WEB-INF directory, because clients do not need to access it directly.
